metadata.case_name: H.H. the Maharana Sahib Shri Bhagwat Singh Bahadur v. State of Rajasthan

facts.text: By order of the President of India, H.H. the Maharana Sahib Shri Bhagwat Singh Bahadur (appellant) was recognised as the Ruler of Udaipur with effect from July 4, 1955 in succession to his father the late Maharana Bhupal Singh.

A dispute arose between the appellant and his employees in the Motor Garage Department about the conditions of employment and representations were made by the latter to the Government of Rajasthan through the Motor Workers Mazdoor Union, Udaipur.

The Government of the State of Rajasthan, on December 18, 1957 referred under s. 10 of the Industrial Disputes Act 14 of 1947, the following dispute to the Industrial Tribunal, Rajasthan: Whether the Maharana Sahib Bahadur of Udaipur is liable to pay to the staff working with him in the Palace Power House and Motor Garage, consequent to their retrenchment, the arrears of claims or the due salary, leave wages, overtime wages and weekly holidays as per schedule appended hereto and if so, to what extent. If not, to what relief the staff is entitled to under the provisions of the Industrial Disputes Act, as the question of payment of the claims has arisen with the termination of their services due to retrenchment effected by the employers.

Two preliminary objections were raised before the Industrial Tribunal by the appellant against the maintainability of the reference: (1) That the reference to the Industrial Tribunal for adjudication of the dispute was not maintainable without the previous sanction of the Central Government to the making of the reference. (2) That on the date when the reference was made no Industrial Tribunal was constituted under s. 7A of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, as amended by Act 36 of 1956, and on reconstitution of the Tribunal, the reference became incompetent.

The Tribunal rejected both the objections and a writ petition filed by the appellant challenging the validity of the order of the Tribunal was dismissed by the High Court of Rajasthan by judgment and order dated March 28, 1962 in D.B. Civil Writ Petition No. 164 of 1961.
The appellant has appealed to this Court, with certificate granted by the High Court of Rajasthan.
Industrial Tribunal for Rajasthan was constituted by notification dated June 2, 1953, under s. 7 of the Industrial Disputes Act.
The Industrial Disputes Act was amended by Act 36 of 1956, deleting s. 7 and enacting ss. 7, 7A, 7B, 7C; power to appoint Tribunal under s. 7A.
High Court of Rajasthan in Writ Petition No. 107 of 1958 (Mundra Metal Works Private Ltd. v. The State of Rajasthan) held that reference to Tribunal constituted under old s. 7 was incompetent.
State Government reconstituted the Tribunal under s. 7A by notification dated April 16, 1959, but no fresh reference of the dispute was made.

Rajasthan Industrial Tribunal Constitution and Proceedings Validating Act, 1959 enacted, reserved for President's consideration and received assent. S.2(1) deems Tribunal constituted under old s.7 as duly constituted under s.7A for period March 10, 1957 to April 15, 1959. S.2(2) deems all references, proceedings, orders in that period valid.

legal_issues.text: Whether the reference to the Industrial Tribunal was maintainable without previous sanction of the Central Government under s. 87B of the Code of Civil Procedure, as the appellant is a Ruler of a former Indian State.

Whether Art. 362 of the Constitution protects the appellant from the reference of the industrial dispute, as it infringes guarantees under the covenant regarding personal rights, privileges and dignities.

Whether the Industrial Tribunal was properly constituted under s. 7A of the Industrial Disputes Act at the time of reference on December 18, 1957, and whether reconstitution required a fresh reference.

petitioner_arguments.text: Without the sanction of the Union Government under s. 87B of the Code of Civil Procedure, the reference to the Industrial Tribunal was incompetent, as s. 86 applies to Rulers of former Indian States.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s. 86, 87B Code of Civil Procedure; Art. 366(22) Constitution

petitioner_arguments.text: Art. 362 preserves personal rights, privileges and dignities under the covenant, entitling the appellant to sovereign immunity from jurisdiction of Industrial Tribunal, akin to foreign sovereigns under international law.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 362 Constitution; Covenant of United State of Rajasthan (Arts. XI-XV)

petitioner_arguments.text: On the date of reference, no Industrial Tribunal was constituted under s. 7A (post-1956 amendment); reconstitution on April 16, 1959 without fresh reference made proceedings incompetent.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Industrial Disputes Act s. 7A; Mundra Metal Works case

respondent_arguments.text: The dispute is under Industrial Disputes Act reference, not a suit in civil court; s. 86 CPC does not apply as no suit is instituted and Tribunal is not a court.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Industrial Disputes Act s. 10; s. 86 CPC

respondent_arguments.text: Rajasthan Industrial Tribunal Constitution and Proceedings Validating Act, 1959 cures any defects in constitution and validates references/proceedings.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Rajasthan Industrial Tribunal Constitution and Proceedings Validating Act, 1959 s. 2

court_reasoning.text: Proceeding under Industrial Disputes Act is not a suit; commences by government reference under s.10, not plaint; Tribunal not a court; s.86 CPC strictly construed does not apply.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Neither party sued; Tribunal not court.

court_reasoning.text: Post-1947, position of Rulers altered; they are citizens of India; Art.362 requires due regard to guarantees under covenants but does not confer sovereign immunity; no evidence plea raised in High Court; not entertainable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rights avail as citizens, not sovereigns; no evidence of specific privilege.

court_reasoning.text: Validating Act deems original Tribunal constituted under s.7A and validates reference/proceedings; within state competence, President's assent; prevails.

holdings.text: Reference under Industrial Disputes Act not barred by s.86/87B CPC as not a suit and Tribunal not court.
Art.362 does not exempt Ruler from industrial dispute adjudication; plea not sustainable without evidence.
Validating Act, 1959 validates Tribunal constitution and reference.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sudhansu Shekhar Singh Deo v. State of Orissa
precedents_cited.relevance: Art.362 recommendation does not permit courts to question legislative/executive action inconsistent with covenants; Art.363 bars jurisdiction.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mundra Metal Works Private Ltd. v. The State of Rajasthan
precedents_cited.citation: Writ Petition No. 107 of 1958 (Rajasthan High Court)
precedents_cited.relevance: Held pre-1956 s.7 Tribunal references incompetent post-amendment.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs reference and constitution of Tribunal; applied to Rajasthan.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Protects Rulers from suits without Central Govt consent; does not apply to industrial references.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art.362: due regard to covenants; recognition of Rulers; bars jurisdiction over covenants.

statutes_cited.name: Rajasthan Industrial Tribunal Constitution and Proceedings Validating Act, 1959
statutes_cited.relevance: Validates Tribunal constitution and proceedings despite defects.

statutes_cited.name: Covenant of United State of Rajasthan
statutes_cited.relevance: Guarantees privy purse, properties, privileges, dignities, succession, immunity for past acts.

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, holding that the reference to the Industrial Tribunal was maintainable without Central Government sanction under CPC, not barred by Art.362, and validated by the 1959 Validating Act. Contentions raised fail.

key_quotes.text: Section 86 of the Code excludes the jurisdiction of the civil courts and must be strictly construed. It does not debar the commencement of proceedings for adjudication of an industrial dispute for two reasons neither party to the proceeding is sued by the initiation of the proceeding, and the Tribunal is not a court.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects s.86 CPC applicability to industrial proceedings.

key_quotes.text: These rights, privileges and dignities which are, for historical reasons, recommended to be respected, avail the Rulers in their status as Indian citizens and not in recognition of any sovereign authority continuing to remain vested in them.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies status of Rulers post-Constitution; no sovereign immunity.

key_quotes.text: The contentions raised in this appeal must therefore fail.
key_quotes.speaker: court
